Award.AwardTitle: Advanced Study Institute on Global Healthcare Grand Challenges and Opportunities Conference on July 21-26, 2013 in Antalya, Turkey

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Metin Akay
Proposal ID: 1301542

The National Academy of Engineering announced the 14 Grand Challenges for Engineering at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. The committee also praised biomedical and biological engineering as the research field to fulfill the promise of personalized medicine. Included among these 14 challenges were Reverse Engineering the Brain, Engineer better Medicines and Advance Health Informatics. An important way of exploiting such information would be through the development of methods that allow doctors to forecast the benefits and side effects of potential treatments or cures. "Reverse Engineering" the Brain, is an emerging discipline that helps us to understand how the brain works and treats several diseases. It furthermore helps us to develop computerized artificial intelligence. Advanced computer intelligence, in turn, should enable automated diagnosis and prescriptions for treatment. Computerized catalogs of health information will enhance the medical system's ability to track the spread of disease and analyze the comparative effectiveness of different approaches to prevention and therapy. Finally, engineering new medicines will help us fight the growing danger of attacks from novel disease-causing agents. For instance, certain deadly bacteria have repeatedly evolved new properties, conferring resistance against even the most powerful antibiotics. New viruses arise with the power to kill and spread more rapidly than disease-prevention systems are designed to counteract.

Intellectual Merits: The main objective of the "Advanced Summer Institute on Global Healthcare--Challenges and Opportunities" is to highlight and discuss these emerging grand challenges, mainly focused on the latest advances in the areas of science, engineering, technology and medicine. The institute provides a unique environment to discuss the emerging research areas, challenges and opportunities which lead to very fruitful discussions.

Broader Impacts: It exposes the attendees with biology and medicine backgrounds to the latest developments in these emerging enabling technologies. It is also helpful to those with engineering and science background who are interested in doing research in bionanoscience and nanomedicine, neuroscience and engineering since the advanced institute provides exceptional insights into the fundamental challenges in biology and medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Healthcare remains among the most critical challenges facing nations across the globe and cuts across medical, social, and economic areas. Developing countries are battling issues ranging from malnutrition to infectious diseases. In the most developed countries, changes in demographics (i.e., the increasing proportion of an older population) and the focus on quality of life will require health care systems to transform in a number of ways. 

Transforming health care along these lines is imperative in order to both reduce disparities and maximize quality of life for all people. In addition to advances in medical science and rethinking how care is provided, technology serves as a catalyst for creating an economically feasible transformation of health care delivery. 

Among the key issues is the development of quantitative and computational models of processes ranging from molecular biology to behavioral. Integrating computation into the biological sciences will have a significant impact on fundamental and applied research. The presentations included a sample of a number of different levels of analysis and application ranging from protein structures and tissue engineering to behavior modification.

The presenters also indicated that there are unprecedented opportunities in the area of neural engineering ranging from basic research, applied and translational research, to health care practice and economic development.  These opportunities derive from spectacular advances both in basic biological science, especially biomolecular advances, and in engineering technologies, including nanoelectronics, computation, and materials. The more global issues involve how to make technology available to broader populations and at what cost, as well determining which new devices will perform well in the medical marketplace.

The speakers represented major areas of neural engineering, including neural culture, algorithm development, brain computer interface design, and motor and sensory control devices.  Specific topics discussed were: a) how to manage the large quantities of data being generated today, b) what can be done to assist the academic community in analyzing these big data sets, and  c) how to build a healthy feedback system to drive new, relevant scientific and technical questions to the next generation technologies. Ethical considerations are critical as well. 

Accomplishing the challenges of the 21st century will require a new and truly trans-disciplinary approach to science. Indeed it is not possible for any one person to be a master of everything, so the ability to work effectively in a team environment should become a cornerstone of all educational programs seeking to train the next generation of successful scientists and engineers.

Biomedical Engineering programs are training the best and brightest undergraduate students. We need to integrate these emerging technologies into the Biomedical Engineering curriculum to foster within students the problem solving abilities necessary for tackling the healthcare challenges of today and tomorrow. Students will need to be appropriately trained in order to be successful in industry, graduate and professional school as well as in other professions. Such training would also promote the hiring of more Biomedical Engineers with B.S. degrees into industry.

 Proper accreditation of educational programs is mandatory to ensure reasonable employability of graduates and defined minimal common engineering education levels. It might also be reasonable to consider junior and senior levels of specialization in the curriculum including neural engineering, systems and synthetic biology health informatics, and biodata-science among biomedical engineers.

 In addition to biomedical engineering curriculum, these emerging technologies are also being considered for integration into medical school curriculum. The UIUC recently started the first engineering based medical school focused on the intersection of emerging engineering innovations (including neural engineering, bio-nanoscience, health informatics, etc.) and medicine. Beginning in Fall 2018, the new medical school will educate a new generation of medical doctors with strong skill sets in the areas of the invention, discovery, problem solving to provide high-quality care to patients. 

Similarly, Texas A&M University (TAMU) and the Houston Methodist Hospital have started a novel program to engineer the future of medicine through the creation of an innovative engineering medical program that seeks to educate future physicians with strong engineering skill sets about emerging technologies that can be used to impact health care and provide high-quality care to their patients. The proposed curriculum will lead to a joint MD and BMEMaster degree. The graduates from this program will be exposed to research and commercialization opportunities.

As educators and researchers, our main challenge is to oversee the implications of these new technologies, educating both engineers and scientists with the ethical implications of such activities.
